Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MSA and your
contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available please contact the area manager at
(616) 204-6992.

ALLEGATION:
Staff member at agency took youth to the store at an unknown date. During this
time, staff member attempted to hug youth and grab youth's penis.
INVESTIGATION:
On 1/12/2022 I received a complaint alleging that Staff 1 had made an inappropriate
sexual advance toward Youth A while the two were alone in Staff 1’s car.
Youth A - On 1/14/2022 I joined DHHS Worker by phone as she interviewed Youth
A in person. Youth A stated that he did not want to discuss details of the allegation.
He stated that another youth in the home must have reported the incident after
hearing Youth A talk about it, because Youth A never wanted to report this. Youth A
stated that on 12/31/21 at approximately 5:00PM he went to the store with Staff 1 in
Staff 1’s car. While seat belted in the car, Staff 1 “made a sexual advance” toward
Youth A by touching his upper left thigh. Youth A responded by saying “we’re not
going to do that” after which Staff 1 acted embarrassed. Youth A stated that Staff 1
worked until 11:00PM that night and there were no further incidents or discussion
about what happened in the car. Youth A reported he has not had any other
concerns with Staff 1 and hasn’t heard of any other youth in the home having
concerns with her either.
On 3/1/2022 we attempted to speak with Youth A again; however, Youth A had told
staff that he did not want to talk to us again and left the home.
DHHS Worker - On 2/15/2022 I talked with DHHS Worker by phone. DHHS Worker
reported Staff 1 was interviewed in person at the police station along with a
detective. DHHS Worker shared other concerning statements made by Staff 1 during
her interview regarding Youth A’s alcohol use in the home while Staff 1 was present,
staff and youth being afraid of Youth A, and Supervisor 1’s lack of responsiveness.
DHHS Worker also reported, during Staff 1’s interview with the DHHS Worker and
detective, Staff 1 made concerning statements about personal self-harm and stated
that she was going to a local mental health facility.
Staff 1 - On 3/11/2022 I interviewed Staff 1 via video conferencing. DHHS Worker
also participated in this interview. Staff 1 stated she drove Youth A to Family Fare on
12/31/2021 but denied having any sexual conversations with him and denied
touching his thigh, leg, or penis. She stated her “theory” is that Youth A is making
the allegation because she called 911 on Youth A for a wellness check and he likely
figured out who made the call. She did; however, admit to sitting in her car with
Youth A smoking cigarettes and listening to music together. Staff 1 was asked if
youth were allowed to smoke with staff, particularly since Youth A is 16 and not of
legal age to have cigarettes to which she replied that it was not allowed, but that
Supervisor 1 had stated she knew Youth A smoked and drank. Staff 1 stated she
would take 1 -2 smoke breaks during her shift and “eventually,” while she was on the
back porch Youth A came out and asked if he could go out there with her, which she
allowed. She added that he had his own cigarettes and that she did not provide any
3

for him, but he would join her for her smoke breaks and smoke with her. She also
admitted to having taken cigarettes that were in the staff office after being
confiscated from a youth, bringing them home, and smoking them herself.
Staff 1 was asked about Youth A’s drinking in the home. She stated that he was
smoking and drinking at the home from the time she started working there so she
just assumed that was “how it was.” She stated she didn’t know if other staff or
supervision knew about his smoking and drinking at the home, but she did know that
Staff 2 had confiscated cigarettes from Youth A. Staff 1 reported Youth A’s drinking
started “little by little.” She stated the first instance was while he was cooking dinner.
Staff 1 stated another staff member had taken him shopping earlier, prior to Staff 1
taking over the shift, and Youth A had a grocery bag with a case of beer which he
told Staff 1 was for cooking. Staff 1 stated she doesn’t know how Youth A got the
beer or if the other staff knew about it. Staff 1 stated she doesn’t know if Youth A
was “testing” her by bringing in the beer. Staff 1 stated she was never trained on
what to do in this situation and that, from there he just kept bringing in alcohol and
drinking. She stated no one had informed her that he had a substance use issue and
she never received a “run down” on Youth A. She reported she had been trained for
2 days by Program Trainer, but she stated that she felt like she needed more
training, so Program Trainer provided her an additional day of training. She reported
no one went over protocol. She also admitted she never asked the trainer, other
staff, or her supervisor what to do after the first incident when Youth A had beer in
the home.
Staff 1 reported Youth A had offered her alcohol at the home, but she didn’t accept.
She stated he proceeded drink in front of her. She reported he would use beer in his
meals while cooking dinner then finish the can. She stated she knew the youth
weren’t supposed to be drinking, but it was happening, so she thought it was ok. She
stated that on 12/27/2021 she heard “hacking” and a “big thud” and found Youth A
face down in the hallway dry heaving, so she “poked him awake.” She stated he
stumbled away. She stated she heard him become “violently ill.” She texted
Supervisor 1 that Youth A was intoxicated but she did not get a response. She
stated she always filled out her staff notes about 1 ½ -2 hours before the end of her
shift and was 99% sure she completed her notes about this incident.
Staff 1 also reported an incident when Youth A was intoxicated and flicking a lighter
attempting to burn one of the couches. She stated she believed he was getting to a
point of overdosing, but she did not reach out to the police, medical, or emergency
services. She then added, “thinking back I was never instructed what to do when
they are suicidal or overdose.” She stated there was a binder in the office which
included staff procedures, but she found that on her own while sitting at the staff
desk 3-4 weeks into her employment. She stated she found all of the protocol and
procedures in the binder at that time. Staff 1 reported she never had an actual
conversation with Supervisor 1 until a “few weeks” into her employment.
4

Staff 1 reported on 12/31/2021 she thought she heard Youth A “violently ill,” but she
wasn’t sure, so she left work. She reported there was another time when she
transported him that he was intoxicated. She also stated there was a time that she
saw him drop something that she thought might have been cocaine, but she wasn’t
sure. She stated that she didn’t report this to anyone.
Staff 1 was asked about calling the police on Youth A. She reported, when she left
work that day, he seemed suicidal, and she went home where she debated and
weighed the fear of what he would do if she called the police against his safety and
ultimately decided to call the police. Staff 1 was asked why she didn’t tell anyone
she was calling 911 and she stated she talked with Supervisor 1 about Youth A’s
behaviors and Supervisor 1 told Staff 1 to leave Youth A alone. She reported she
texted Supervisor 1 on the night she called 911 and Supervisor 1 attempted to call
her, but Staff 1 was charging her phone and wasn’t able to answer. Supervisor 1 did
text to ask with whom Staff 1 was having concerns and when Staff 1 replied with
Youth A’s name, Supervisor 1 stopped responding. She stated she did not have a
chance to document anything about Youth A’s behavior that night because she had
already typed her notes before he started making what she described as suicidal
and homicidal statements.
Staff 1 stated she was concerned for the safety of the youth and had never had a job
like this before. She stated she was “just trying to figure it out.” She stated things
might have been better if she was trained directly by Supervisor 1. She reported she
wasn’t sure if this was the job for her right away and that she wasn’t comfortable
being the only staff working with clients. She stated she never wants a job like that
again and will always have a co-worker with her to “hold me accountable and to
confide in.”
On 3/14/2022 I received and reviewed an email from Staff 1 in which she reported
that she interviewed for her position at the agency on 11/15/2021 with Program
Supervisor who discussed topics such as youth using tobacco and marijuana during
their stay at the home. Staff 1 reported Program Supervisor expresses that she
wasn’t concerned with this and does not view these things as illegal despite the
youth being under the age of 21 and that the police don’t take it seriously either.
Staff 1 reported Program Supervisor told her about a youth using heroin in one of
the homes, which Program Supervisor knowingly allowed. Staff 1 also reported on
12/21/2021, Supervisor 1 and Program Supervisor were at the home setting up a
Christmas tree for a holiday decorating competition when Staff 1 arrived to work at
3:00 PM. Staff 1 reported Youth A was drinking something from a cup in front of
everyone and could not hold a conversation without laughing, could not walk
straight, and was leaning on door frames to hold himself up. She reported Youth A
could not participate in the decorating because he knocked over anything he
touched and at one point fell to the floor while staff, including Supervisor 1, laughed
at him rather than helping him up. Staff 1 reported the decorating was live streamed
to other agency homes and Youth A was unable to participate because “his
5

condition had worsened.” She reported after the competitions, he continued to drink
out of his cup while eating pizza with Supervisor 1 and the other staff and youth.
Supervisor 1 - On 1/17/2022 (in person,) 3/1/2022 (by phone,) and 3/15/2022
(virtually,) I interviewed Supervisor 1. Supervisor 1 reported she was Staff 1’s
supervisor and is also Youth A’s case manager. Supervisor 1 reported she became
aware of this allegation when she was told by a staff member that another youth in
the home reported Youth A made the allegation while the youth were in a group
setting. Supervisor indicated Staff 1 worked for the agency for 1.5 – 2 months and
didn’t work many shifts. Supervisor 1 was asked about the home policy regarding
staff transporting youth and she reported staff are supposed to get permission
before transporting youth and there should always be at least two youth in the car
when staff do transport. She stated there is a binder in the staff office which contains
staff procedures including what to do when staff find drugs or alcohol in the home,
youth are intoxicated, or youth become violent or suicidal.
Supervisor 1 was asked about Youth A’s substance use. Supervisor 1 stated she
had talked with Staff 1 about Youth A’s substance abuse history and his
susceptibility to relapse, so Staff 1 would not have had any reason to believe it was
acceptable for him to drink in the home. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A has relapsed
due to the stress of this investigation. DHHS Worker reported to Supervisor 1 she
had spoken with Youth A’s probation officer who told DHHS Worker that Youth A
relapsed prior to this investigation initiation and admitted to drinking every day for a
month. Additionally, staff reported his use in the home prior to this investigation.
Supervisor 1 reported Youth A self-disclosed a relapse with alcohol on 2/1/2022. At
that time, his services were enhanced by adding a second therapist and a mentor.
Youth A also has a probation officer who implemented community service based on
the relapse. Supervisor 1 reported they have team meetings every two weeks during
which they discuss the needs and concerns of each youth in the home; however,
Staff 1 did not attend the majority of the meetings held while she was employed.
She reported that she was not aware of Youth A drinking in the home while Staff 1
was present at any time. She stated Staff 1’s reports about Youth A being
intoxicated during the Christmas tree decorating are untrue. She stated Youth A did
participate in the decorating and the live stream event. She reported he was drinking
soda during the event, not alcohol.
Supervisor 1 was asked about the incident when Staff 1 called the police on Youth
A. Supervisor 1 stated she doesn’t know why Staff 1 called for a welfare check on
Youth A as she had not contacted Supervisor 1 or anyone else to express any
concerns. Supervisor 1 stated Youth A was assessed at the emergency room and
deemed to not be threat to himself or others, so he was brought back to the home.
DHHS Worker asked Supervisor 1 if she was aware that Youth A was intoxicated
when he was taken to the emergency room, and she stated that she reviewed the
medical paperwork but “must have missed that.”
6

Supervisor 1 stated she has talked to all of the youth in the home, and no one is
afraid of Youth A. Additionally, she stated Program Manager is adamant about
pressing charges if staff feel threatened and no one has expressed feeling
threatened by Youth A. Supervisor 1 stated any staff who have had any concerns
with Youth A for any reason have let Supervisor 1 know. Supervisor 1 stated when
Youth A is observed pacing around, panicing, repeating himself, staring off, and
upset, Youth A can seem scary when he is acting this way, but that he is not a
threat. She stated she has never seen him physically aggressive or express suicidal
or homicidal statement. She stated staff should be documenting these behaviors if
they are occurring, but there has been nothing of this nature in case notes.
Program Manager - On 1/17/2022 I interviewed Program Manager 1 on-site.
Program Manager reported she had a phone conversation with Staff 1 on 1/12/2022
during which Staff 1 reported Youth B is afraid of Youth A. Staff 1 did not talk about
any other youth or any other concerns during her call with Program Manager.
Program Manager reported no other staff or youth share the concerns about Youth A
expressed by Staff 1.
During my interview of Program Manager and Supervisor 1, I was able to put
together the following timeline of events based on their reports regarding the
allegations:
Friday 12/31/21
 Approximately 5:00PM: Allegedly, Staff 1 drove Youth A to Family Fare.
 11:00 PM: Staff 1’s shift is over, and she leaves.
 Shortly after 11 PM: Third shift staff catch Youth A with a 6 pack of beer in his
room.
Monday 1/3/22
 3:00 PM Staff 1 works for the first time since 12/31/21.
 The home supervisor notifies the staff that Youth A was found with the beer on
12/31/21.
 5:00 PM Staff 1 calls police reporting concerns that Youth A has made suicidal
and homicidal comments. Staff 1 does not tell anyone she made this call despite
being at work.
 7:00 PM Staff 1’s shift ends, and she goes home.
 Later that evening, Staff 1 calls Supervisor 1 to report that she is unable to sleep
because she does not feel that the home is safe with Youth A there and she is
concerned Youth A will slit the third shift staff throats, despite third shift staff not
working for another 3 days.
 Supervisor tells Staff 1 she will leave her phone on all night in case Staff 1
needed anything, but Staff 1 never calls.
 10:00 PM The police arrive at the home. Youth A has no idea why he is taken
away. He is assessed at the hospital for the report of mental health concerns and
is brought back to the home 2 hours later.
7

 Supervisor 1 calls Staff 1 to ask why she never told anyone she had called the
police at 5PM. Staff 1 is hyper-focused on the fact that Youth A is back at the
home and insists he needs to go to jail.
 Staff 1 refuses to work her next 3 scheduled shifts claiming she does not feel
safe.
 Program Supervisor informs Staff 1 that agency policy indicates that three no-
shows result in termination.
 Staff 1 contacts the agency Program Manager indicating she needs to speak with
her.
 Program Manager schedules a phone meeting with Staff 1 for 1/12/22 at which
time Staff 1 resigns.
Monday 1/10/22
 During a house meeting with the youth, it comes up that Staff 1 will not be
coming back to work. Youth A allegedly makes a statement in front of his peers
that Staff 1 shouldn’t be there anyway and makes a statement about her having
touched him and trying to touch his penis.
Tuesday 1/11
 One of Youth A’s peers tells a staff member about Youth A’s allegations.
Wednesday 1/12
 A staff member tells Supervisor 1 about the allegations after which Supervisor 1
makes a DHHS report.
 Program Manager holds her already scheduled call with Staff 1 who makes a
variety of allegations against Youth A including:
- suspected cocaine use
- theft of other youth’s meds to use and/or sell
- being drunk daily in the home.
Program Trainer – On 2/15/2022 I interviewed Program Trainer along with DHHS
Worker by phone. Program Trainer reported she is responsible for training the home
staff and that she provided the training to Program Trainer. She stated she did not
have any information about the allegation but stated that if Staff 1 transported Youth
A alone in her car she was in violation of protocol. She reported she did have
concerns with Staff 1 as an employee and there were “red flags” whenever she was
working because the youth wouldn’t talk to Program Trainer while Staff 1 was
working. Program Trainer would stop by the home to check in to see if Staff 1, as a
new staff, was following protocol. Staff 1 would seem nervous. Program Trainer
stated once when she showed up Staff 1 told the youth to quickly pick up something
that was broken. Program Trainer stated she noticed Staff 1 would be upstairs
drawing while the youth were downstairs. Program Trainer stated the youth told her
that they were not comfortable with Staff 1, especially Youth A, but Program Trainer
did not know why. Program Trainer stated Youth A asked her if Staff 1 had
completed a background check. Program Trainer told Youth A that he could reach
out to her anytime and Youth A stated that he didn’t feel comfortable doing so.
8

Program Trainer stated the staff members are to complete a daily report for each
youth in the home and Staff 1 never reported Youth A drinking or being drunk.
Program Trainer stated if Staff 1 was aware of Youth A using or being under the
influence of any substance and didn’t inform anyone, she was violating protocol.
Program Supervisor – On 3/15/2022 I interviewed Program Supervisor along with
DHHS Worker via a virtual conference. Program Supervisor denied minimizing
youth’s use of tobacco and alcohol to Staff 1 during her interview. She reported she
did talk to Staff 1 about youth experimenting with cigarettes, vapes, marijuana, etc.
and talked about the struggles they have had with police not taking these concerns
seriously when they are contacted due to the substances being legal, even if the
youth are underage. She stated that she talked to Staff 1 about utilizing programs to
help youth stay away from their use triggers. She states she talked about an incident
when staff had to safety plan for a youth who was using heroine but did not express
that this was allowed.
Program Supervisor reported she was present when Supervisor 1 spoke to Staff 1
about Youth A’s substance use issues. Program Supervisor was also present when
Program Trainer talked with Staff 1 about Youth A’s substance use concerns and
what staff were supposed to watch for regarding possible relapse.
Staff 2 - On 2/15/2022 I interviewed Staff 2 by phone along with DHHS Worker. Staff
2 was asked about the inappropriate touch allegation. Staff 2 stated that she can’t
recall the specific date, but Youth B talked to her about Staff 1 stating “she’s not
working here anymore?” When Staff 2 confirmed that she was not, Youth B seemed
relieved. Youth B told Staff 2 that Youth A had told him about Staff 1 trying to grab
Youth A’s penis on 12/31/2021 while in Staff 1’s car. Staff 2 stated that she only saw
Staff 1 and Youth A together on the Monday Staff 1 called the police on Youth A.
During that shift, Staff 1 had pepper spray around her neck and said that Youth B
was afraid of Youth A. Youth A came into the house, stood near the kitchen and
asked to talk to Staff 1 who then went downstairs with Youth A. After Staff 1 left work
that day, she texted Staff 2 and told Staff 2 to text her when she left work. It was
after Staff 2 texted Staff 1 that she left the house after her shift ended that Staff 1
called the police. Staff 2 stated that she didn’t know why the police were called. Staff
2 stated, the next day, Staff 1 called her and said Youth A was suicidal and “saying
crazy things.”
Staff 2 was asked about Staff 1 as an employee and about the drinking allegations
and she stated that she assumes Staff 1 was having inappropriate and
unprofessional conversation with the youth because Staff 1 would talk to Staff 2
about things that concerned her such as her and her boyfriend’s mental health
issues. Staff 2 stated that she had minimal interaction with Staff 1 because they
worked different shifts, but Staff 2 told her Youth A told Staff 1 he was using alcohol.
Staff 2 stated that she never observed Youth A drinking or drunk in the home, but
third shift staff found him intoxicated that he was throwing up in the home on
12/31/2021. Staff 2 stated that she didn’t know where Youth A got the alcohol.
9

Staff 2 reported she recently left her position with the agency because Youth A was
threatening her after she caught him with cigarettes on Thanksgiving. Staff 2 stated
Youth A tried to pay her off to not tell anyone about the cigarettes. She stated he
said he wanted her dead and wanted to “pop the heads off” the third shift staff. She
stated he would pace around the home, yelling, talking to the cameras, and his body
language and the look in his eyes made her feel as if he was plotting her death. She
stated he was always rude and acted angry unless Supervisor 1 was in the home.
Staff 2 reported Supervisor 1 always sticks up for Youth A and when Staff 2 sent
Supervisor 1 emails or talked to her about Youth A’s behavior, Supervisor 1 would
“pass it off as words.”
Staff 3 - On 3/8/2022 I interviewed Staff 3 by phone along with DHHS Worker. Staff
3 reported that he hasn’t heard anything about Youth A and Staff 1. He stated Staff 1
was always following the rules and was “serious” about her job. He stated that he
didn’t have concerns with her physical boundaries, but Youth A and another youth
told him that Staff 1 talked with them about her personal life issues.
Staff 3 reported he caught Youth A with alcohol an 12/31/2021 and Youth A was
intoxicated. He stated that it seemed like Youth A had made his own alcohol
because there was a cup in the bathroom with an orange drink and hand sanitizer
was next to it. Staff 3 stated Youth A had consumed 4 “Locos” and possibly the
orange drink on that night. Youth A vomited and helped Staff 3 clean up his room
that night. Staff 3 stated he talked this through with Youth A that night and he
seemed ok, so he reported it at the end of his shift which was the next morning. Staff
3 reported a couple of weeks later he found alcohol in the bathroom and a mixed
drink on the table. Staff 3 stated he checked on Youth A, who was asleep, and he
seemed fine, so Staff 3 took pictures of the alcohol and sent them to Supervisor 1.
Staff 3 stated Youth A told him that he gets alcohol from a guy at the corner gas
station. Staff 3 reported the protocol for staff if a youth has alcohol or is intoxicate is
to report it to Supervisor 1. Staff 3 said the staff are also to take pictures and send
them to Supervisor 1, which Staff 3 did via email and text. Staff 3 stated Youth A has
never consumed alcohol in front of him, but he did ask Staff 3 to not tell when Staff 3
found the alcohol. Staff 3 reported it to his superiors “because that’s my job.” He
reported Youth A became angry at Staff 3 for reporting him. Staff 3 stated Staff 1
told him that Youth A was making verbal threats and Staff 1 was scared. Staff 3
stated he has heard Youth A make verbal threats before when he was angry, and he
was aware that Youth A had made a verbal threat against Staff 3 regarding this
incident but didn’t know the police were called by Staff 1 or that Youth A went to the
hospital. Staff 3 stated Youth A has anger issues he needs to work on.
Staff 3 reported after the first drinking incident, they had a staff meeting during which
Supervisor 1 asked if anyone had any issues with Youth A. Staff 1 responded “a lot.”
Staff 3 stated he agreed with Staff 1’s statement. Staff 3 stated Supervisor 1
downplayed the concerns then dismissed them entirely. Staff 3 stated Staff 1 felt
unheard and said she was going to talk to someone higher up. Staff 3 stated he
10

thinks Supervisor 1 takes the concerns with Youth A seriously, but she downplays
some of it because she sees Youth A’s potential.
Staff 3 stated when staff brought up the drinking concerns to Supervisor 1 after the
second incident Staff 3 described, she said she would contact Youth A’s probation
officer. After that, Youth A’s services were increased. Staff 3 also stated staff are
now to do increased walkthroughs of the home to check on Youth A and that the
staff meetings have been increased from every two weeks to every week.
Youth B - On 3/1/2022 I interviewed Youth B by phone while DHHS Worker was
with him in person. Youth B reported when he first moved into the home, Staff 1 was
“good, helpful.” He stated after time she started to talk about her time in “mental
hospitals” and other personal issues such as her past drug problems. Youth B stated
he didn’t want to talk about anything happening between Staff 1 and Youth A, but he
agreed that a statement was made to him about something happening with Staff 1
and Youth A on 12/31/21. The only thing Youth B would state was, after he and
some other youth returned from a trip to the mall on 12/31/2021 Youth A told Youth
B that Youth A got Staff 1 to take him to Family Fare to get food. Youth B stated that
Youth A told him that while Staff 1 was in the car with Youth A, Staff 1 was reaching
for him. Youth B did not want to provide any other detail, stating Youth A asked him
not to tell anyone. Youth B stated that after this incident Staff 1 only worked one
other shift.
Youth B stated that the night the police came for Youth A, Youth B woke up in the
middle of the night to the sound of ambulances. He reported he heard this was
because Staff 1 accused Youth A of using crack. Youth B stated he and Youth A are
close and talk a lot and Youth A has never talked about crack. Youth B was asked
about Youth A’s alcohol use in the home to which Youth A responded, “no
comment.” Youth B did state Youth B had never smoked or consumed alcohol with
Staff 1 and never saw Staff 1 drink nor did he smell alcohol on her. Youth B stated
that he has never been afraid of Youth A and the two of them joke around a lot.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
 Staff 1’s training transcripts documenting she participated in 11 hours of training
which included, program orientation, de-escalation techniques, compliance and
ethics, mandatory reporting of abuse & neglect, safety training, and review of the
safety guidelines handbook.
 Program staff training plan outlining the required training, all of which was
documented to have been completed by Staff 1.
 Employee orientation checklist which includes reviewing site specific “Security
and Emergency Handbook” as well as “crisis and emergency situations” and
“behavior management and house rules.” This form documented that Staff 1 was
trained on each of these on 12/1/2021; however, did not have Staff 1’s signature
11

despite the form stating that the employee and supervisor must sign prior to
assuming full work responsibilities.
 Acknowledgment of handbook receipt electronically signed by Staff 1 on
11/18/201.
 Staff notes covering December 24, 2021, through February 20, 2022, in which
